projects.title: Team Structure Visualisation
description: Primary Frontend developer of a highly dynamic and responsive internal frontend application aimed at demystifying complex agile team structures across Woolworths Group's 200k+ employee base. This was a greenfield project, and a rewarding collaborative effort with design, business, and backend engineers.

The main features are the intuitive graph, where the key information of each team or employee is displayed, along with a sidepanel, containing more information and a list view of the graph - this was elevated and optimised for mobile.

The app empowers every employee to easily visualise and explore their own team's place, and the broader organisational connections, transcending the limitations of static organisational charts. This critical internal tool, significantly improved organisational clarity and discoverability.
Due to its internal corporate nature I can not provide imagery on this page, feel free to ask me about it!

projects.title: Workflows
description: Tackled inefficient manual processes for team and member structural changes by developing automated workflows for requests and approvals of changes to team members, such as allocation to a squad or changes to the role.

The submitted request can be viewed in a workflow detail view by the initator, admin, or home line manager, where each step which has been performed on the workflow, along with the detailed changes, is laid out. Along with this an admin portal was developed, displaying a list view of all workflow requests along with the ability to perform actions on them. Both detail view and admin portal include real-time updates through polling

I developed the whole detail view, the action buttons and error handling of the admin portal, along with the polling component for both sites. I also helped in the backend with some validation and generation of the steps to display on the detail page.
The introduction of these features drastically reduced human errors, leading to a marked improvement in operational efficiency and transparency.
Due to its internal corporate nature I can not provide imagery on this page, feel free to ask me about it!

projects.title: Design System Components
description: I contributed substantially to Woolworths Group's internal Design System, fostering consistent UI/UX across various platforms. I developed components using Lit, prioritising high performance, reusability, and scalability.
A core principle was the intelligent application of Web Components' slot mechanic, preventing unwieldy prop drilling, as well as promoting ease of use and serialisability.
Storybook was heavily used in this development, enabling us to build robust components and achieve comprehensive test coverage for all their diverse states.

media.title: Screenshot of design system in Storybook

projects.title: Reporting pages
description: Developed a versatile framework to show filterable reports in a table. By maintaining a strict separation of concerns, the underlying structure will display one or more tables along with filters - without any domain knowledge.
Two views exist that access different backend APIs to show different kinds of data.

projects.title: MultiViz - Visualising diversity and liveability in Australian Cities, Vancouver and Auckland
description: This tool provides valuable insight of diversity in cities.
Using Mapbox and the curated dataset (between 20 and 30 MB), a multitude of diversity or liveability indices, such as ethnic, income, gender diversity are mapped to the neighbourhoods of the cities.

There are multiple dimensions to be mapped to visual channels there, such as the colour of the map, but also bars that are rendered on top - height, width and colour of those bars can be mapped to parameters as well.
By hovering over the colours in the menu, the visualisation updates immediately, and one can interact with the bars or apply filters in the menu.
projects.workplace: Monash Data Science and AI Platform

projects.title: IMP - Integrated Microscopy and Electronics
description: An ARDC project in close collaboration with Electron Microscopy at Monash University. I extended an existing framework, Neuroglancer, to be able to show a differenc kind of data and customise it

Neuroglancer is a powerful, WebGL-based viewer for volumetric data, primarily used in neuroscience to visualize extremely large 3D datasets like electron microscopy images of brains. The EM datsets are different and I also set up a pipeline in Python to convert them to the correct format.

In addition, I tweaked the menu and added more functionalities, such as being able to filter objects in the renderer, colour them in different colours or assign them to custom groups to toggle on and off.
Lastly I built a ReactJS portal page, incorporating OAuth, for dataset selection.
projects.workplace: Monash Data Science and AI Platform

projects.title: Global Encounters
description: Contributed frontend features to Global Encounters, an interactive digital humanities project exploring 1000 years of coastal interactions in Australia.
projects.workplace: Monash Data Science and AI Platform

projects.title: Trust Experiment
description: A web-based card game incorporating AI advice logic to enable research on trust in AI agent based systems
The users had to play the game, while getting alerts about an aged care facility, and had to decide whether to react or not, with an agent giving advice.
The backend was a Google Sheet. Researchers had several sheets for different scenarios.

projects.title: Introductory workshop for Frontend Vis
description: Conceptualised, designed and delivered a workshop for introductory web visualisation. This included interactive exercises, live CodePen demos, and slide content.
The participants learned step by step how to create a simple visualisation of provided data, using ChartJS.
projects.workplace: Monash Data Science and AI Platform

projects.title: Agent Simulation
description: Simulated student movement scenarios for campus planning using ECS in Unity. Real student schedule data was used to approximate the targets of the agents.
It was possible to add an obstacle on a path to observe the change of pathfinding for the agents.

projects.title: Scrollyteller
description: Inspired by the at the time rising popularity of scrollytellers, I played around with a system to allow users to add their content via JSON and generate a scrollyteller.
The idea was that other parameters, such as locations on a map, display of a certain image or video, could be linked to positions of the scroll.
It is unfinished, and a lot of it is deprecated now (and I would do things differently now as well), but check out the proof of concept using public Australian power production data below.
I am planning to work on a modern version of this, so stay tuned.

url.title: Australian Energy production distribution over the years
